[16]I've been catching up on my reading. 
[17]Champaran stirred the whole country. They are calling you Mahatma -- the Great Soul. 
[18]I think if we all worked to publicize it... all of the Congress... every avenue we know. 
[19]Bapu... 
[20]It seems less formal than "Mahatma." 
[21]Since your arrest the riots have hardly stopped. Not big --; but they keep breaking out. I run to stop them... and Patel and Kripalani -- they are never at rest. But some English civilians have been killed, and the Army is attacking crowds with clubs -- and sometimes worse. 
[22]The Government's afraid, and they don't know what to do. But they're more afraid of terrorists than of you. The Viceroy has agreed to your release if you will speak for non- violence. 
[23]What can we do? 
[24]It was one incident. 
[25]Bapu -- the whole nation is marching. They wouldn't stop, even if we asked them to. 
[26]But -- but Gandhiji people are aroused... they won't stop. 
[27]Jinnah, Patel, all of Congress has called for the end of non-co- operation. There's not been one demonstration. All over India people are praying that you will end the fast. They're walking in the streets, offering garlands to the police -- and to British soldiers. 
[28]You can't be serious! This man has just stopped a revolution! 
[29]I don't believe it -- even the British can't be that stupid! 
[30]We're not beginners anymore. We've been trained by a strict sergeant major. 
[31]We must get these to the printer. I know it will succeed. Even my mother is prepared to march. 
[32]He's waiting. He's not prepared to accept it will mean as much as you think. 
[33]No violence, Zia! 
[34]...no violence. 
[35]I'm an illegal trader in salt. 
[36]I say when is now -- and we will determine how. 
[37]"Mud packs." 
[38]The "real India" has Muslims and Hindus in every village and every city! How do you propose to separate them? 
[39]Bapu, for me, and the rest, if that is what you want, we will accept it. But out there already there is rioting because Hindus fear you are going to give too much away. 
[40]No. There just are not that many troops. 
[41]What he can! 
[42]He was right. It's insane -- anything would have been better. 
[43]He's in Noakhali. 
[44]He's tramping from village to village -- no police, no troops -- trying to quell the madness single-handedly. Maulana has gone to bring him back. 
[45]In Calcutta it's like civil war. The Muslims rose and there was a bloodbath, and now the Hindus are taking revenge -- and if we can't stop it there'll be no hope for the Hindus left in Pakistan. 
[46]Nothing -- nothing. The divisions in Bombay and Delhi can hardly keep the peace now. And each fresh bit of news creates another wave of  mad... ness. 
[47]Bapu -- please. Where are you going. 
[48]No! There will not be a Hindu Police and a Muslim Police. There is one police! 
[49]Why must I read news like this in the paper? 
[50]Tell Patel. Arrange a plane. We will go -- Friday. 
[51]Bapu... 
[52]Bapu, forgive me -- I've cheated. I could have come earlier. But your fast has helped. These last days people's minds have begun to turn to this bed -- and away from last night's atrocity. But now it is enough. 
[53]Tomorrow five thousand Muslim students of all ages are marching here in Calcutta -- for peace. And five thousand Hindu students are marching with them. It is all organized. 
[54]Bapu, you are not so young anymore. 
[55]Who dares say such things! Who?! Come! Kill me first! Come! Where are you?! Kill me first! 
[56]Bapu, I have brought Mr. Suhrawardy. It was he who called on the Muslims to rise; he is telling them now to go back to their homes, to lay down their arms. 
[57]Think what you can do by living -- that you cannot do by dying. 
[58]What do you want? 
[59]...Sometimes it is when you are quite without hope and in utter darkness that God comes to the rescue. Gandhiji is dying because of our madness. Put away your "revenge." What will be gained by more killing? Have the courage to do what you know is right. For God's sake, let us embrace like brothers... 
[60]You see, Bapu, it is not difficult. I have fasted only a few hours and I accomplished what you could not do in as many days.
dialogues.BA:
[1]Let me go! 
[2]I wish you were still struggling for work in Bombay. 
[3]As I told you about English policemen. 
[4]Be careful! 
[5]They are boys. -- And they're Indian. 
[6]Are you sure? 
[7]Mr. Khan said they called you brave. 
[8]I could have told them you were merely foolish. 
[9]There... 
[10]Not always. You have told me twice now that you were giving up the pleasures of the flesh. 
[11]If you enjoy it a great deal you must fast for two days. 
[12]I will tell Sora. 
[13]Sora was sent to tell me I -- I must rake and cover the latrine. 
[14]It is the work of untouchables. 
[15]I am your wife. 
[16]As you command. 
[17]The others may follow you -- but you forget, I knew you when you were a boy! 
[18]Not at all then... 
[19]Stop it! Stop it! What are you doing!? 
[20]Have you no shame? I'm your wife... Where do you expect me to go? 
[21]You are human -- only human. 
[22]And it is even harder for those of us who do not even want to be as good as you do. 
[23]...And I must rake and cover the latrine. 
[24]My dignity comes from following my husband. 
[25]Please! You're being foolish! 
[26]Charlie! Be careful!! 
[27]Please, God, no! 
[28]The fire is ready. 
[29]But it's the ink that is the most diffic -- 
[30]...but now something worse is happening. When Gandhiji and I were growing up, women wove their own cloth. But now there are millions who have no work because those who can buy all they need from England. I say with Gandhiji, there is no beauty in the finest cloth if it makes hunger and unhappiness. 
[31]Stop -- stop... 
[32]God gave you ten thumbs. 
[33]First lesson: To march, wear shoes, to spin, do not. 
[34]I'll teach you all our foolishness, and you must teach me yours. 
[35]I must get ready for evening prayers. Mirabehn is here. 
[36]"In every worthy wish of yours, I shall be your helpmate." 
[37]"I will ever live devoted to you, speaking words of love and praying for your happiness." 
[38]"I will follow close behind you and help to serve the people." 
[39]"I will follow you in all our vows and duties." 
[40]"You are my best friend... my highest guru, and my sovereign lord." 
[41]And I put a sweetened wheat cake in his mouth. 
[42]You should be relaxing. 
[43]If you take my husband, I intend to speak in his place. 
[44]...not at all. Bapu has always said there were two kinds of slavery in India -- one for women, one for the untouchables -- and he has always fought against both. 
[45]Yes... but we see each other in the day. 
[46]In Hindu philosophy the way to God is to free yourself of possessions -- and the passions that inflame to anger and jealousy. Bapu has always struggled to find the way to God. 
[47]Four times he tried -- and failed. But then he took a solemn vow... 
[48]Not yet.
dialogues.PATEL:
[1]That's young Nehru. He's got his father's intellect, his mother's looks and the devil's charm. If they don't ruin him at Cambridge -- Wave! Wave! -- he may amount to something. 
[2]I must say when I first saw you as a bumbling lawyer here in Bombay I never thought I'd be greeting you as a national hero. 
[3]Oh, yes, you are. It's been two hundred years since an Indian has cocked a snoot at the British Empire and got away with it. And stop calling me Mr. Patel, you're not a junior clerk anymore. 
[4]The new Military Governor of the North West Province was on that ship. Too bad you came back Third Class -- he might have been impressed by a successful barrister who had outmaneuvered General Smuts. 
[5]I agree with Jinnah. Now that the Americans are in, the war will end soon. The Germans are worn out as it is... and our first act should be to convene a Congress Party convention and demand independence. 
[6]Ah -- we should invite Gandhi. What the devil has happened to him anyway? 
[7]And let no one question that Mr. Jinnah speaks not just for the Muslims -- but for all India! 
[8]And now I'm going to introduce to you a man whose writings we are all becoming familiar with... a man who stood high in the esteem of our beloved Professor Gokhale... a man whose accomplishment in South Africa will always be remembered. Mr. Mohandas Gandhi. 
[9]Your journal has made a great impact. 
[10]But it's true! I -- I read it... often. 
[11]No -- but I think I'm going to. 
[12]has been admitted to the power circle, he is not the power 
[13]Your writings are specifically listed. 
[14]diplomatically -- but with a trace of condescension 
[15]My God, it would terrify them... 
[16]Excuse me -- just let me get out of your way, please. No, thank you, I'll manage. 
[17]Ah, Herman! No, no -- don't destroy my good intentions. I'm feeling guilty about traveling Second Class. 
[18]Ah, in that case! 
[19]Maulana is made of sterner stuff. Our trains met in Bombay, but he's back there in that lot somewhere. 
[20]When I think what our "beloved Mahatma" asks, I don't know how he ever got such a hold over us. Is he back? 
[21]Of course. A Muslim beef eater -- I'm only surprised he missed. 
[22]Ah, that explains it. Well, do I carry your luggage as penance or -- 
[23]And what does the daughter of an English admiral propose to do in an ashram -- sink us? 
[24]The irresponsible young Nehru is in prison -- again. Though there is a rumor that under pressure from your country, they will let him out -- again. 
[25]Well, in this country one must decide if one is more afraid of the government or Gandhi. For us, it's Gandhi. 
[26]It must have been the only Non-violent campaign ever led by a man who wanted to kill everybody every day. 
[27]Gandhiji -- do you know the sacrifices people have made? 
[28]That's when you take advantage. 
[29]Mohammed -- the Muslims are in a majority on two different sides of the country. 
[30]If you did this, no one could control it. No one. 
[31]Have you found him? 
[32]...an eye for an eye making the whole world blind. 
[33]Could we cut all news off? I know -- 
[34]We need your help! 
[35]If I fast I die. If you fast people go to all sorts of trouble to keep you alive. 
[36]Everywhere. 
[37]No, he'll be remembered for tempting fate.
dialogues.CHARLIE:
[1]You'd be Gandhi -- ...I thought you'd be bigger. 
[2]I -- I mean it's all right. It doesn't matter. I'm -- my name is Andrews, Charlie Andrews. I've come from India -- I've read a great deal about you. 
[3]Yes. I've -- I've met some very remarkable people in India... and -- and when I read what you've been doing here, I -- I wanted to help. Does that surprise you? 
[4]Perhaps I should -- 
[5]I think perhaps the phrase was used metaphorically... I don't think our Lord meant -- 
[6]That was lucky. 
[7]I am. But I'm not so egotistical as to think He plans His day around my dilemmas. 
[8]That's the sort of thing you'll be seeking on this "farm"... 
[9]Some of you may be rejoicing that Mr. Gandhi has at last been put into prison. 
[10]But I would ask you -- assembled here in this house of God -- to recognize that we are witnessing something new, something so unexpected, so unusual that it is not surprising the Government is at a loss. What Mr. Gandhi has forced us to do is ask questions about ourselves. 
[11]As Christians, those are difficult questions to answer. How do we treat men who defy an unjust law -- men who will not fight, but will not comply? 
[12]May I? Mohan -- I would like you to meet someone. 
[13]I lied to you, Mohan, when I told you I decided to come to South Africa to meet you. Professor Gokhale sent me. 
[14]All right -- I'll go and write my report to the Viceroy. 
[15]No violence, please. 
[16]Going nearer to God! 
[17]Mohan -- !! 
[18]Yes, yes, I'm a Christian. 
[19]Ah, you'll find him under the tree by the river. You'd better leave the car -- the ground is rather soft. 
[20]I wish to see the prisoner, please. 
[21]...Shades of South Africa. 
[22]Did they take your clothes? 
[23]You always had a puritanical streak, Mohan. 
[24]I think you do. But I thank God we all don't. 
[25]Ah, but my puritanism runs the another way. I'm far too modest for such a display. 
[26]Couldn't I be let in with the prisoner? I am a clergyman. 
[27]They're calling you "Bapu." I thought it meant father. 
[28]What do you want me to do? 
[29]I must leave from Calcutta, and soon. You'll have to say goodbye to Ba for me. 
[30]Well, I --
dialogues.JINNAH:
[1]We hope you intend to join us in the struggle for Home Rule, Mr. Gandhi. 
[2]Is he a fool? 
[3]And we must speak with one voice -- united. 
[4]Which is a lot better than causing trouble where it matters. Invite him -- let him say his piece about South Africa -- and then let him slip into oblivion. 
[5]We were asked for toleration. We were asked for patience. Some gave it and some did not. Well, their war is over! And those of us who supported it, and those of us who refused must forget our differences! 
[6]And there can be no excuses from the British now! India wants Home Rule! India demands Home Rule!! 
[7]Where is Mr. Gandhi? 
[8]The Prophet give me patience. 
[9]My house is honored. 
[10]I'll send my gardener. I'm sure you'll have much to discuss. 
[11]Gentlemen -- the hero of Champaran. 
[12]Mr. Patel you know. Mr. Maulana Azad -- a fellow Muslim... recently released from prison. 
[13]Mr. Kripalani. And of course you know Mr. Nehru. 
[14]There is only one answer to that. Direct action -- on a scale they can never handle! 
[15]I too have read Mr. Gandhi's writings, but I'd rather be ruled by an Indian terrorist than an English one. And I don't want to submit to that kind of law. 
[16]You mean a general strike? 
[17]Perhaps I should have stayed in the garden and talked about the flowers. 
[18]After what they did at the massacre -- it's only an eye for an eye. 
[19]We would never get the same commitment again -- ever. 
[20]God! You can be sure the British won't censor that! They'll put it on every street corner. 
[21]So the truth is, after all your travels, all your efforts, they've stopped the campaign and sent you home empty-handed. 
[22]Precisely. 
[23]I don't give a damn for the independence of India! I am concerned about the slavery of Muslims! 
[24]I will not sit by to see the mastery of the British replaced by the mastery of the Hindus! 
[25]The world is not made of Mahatma Gandhis. I am talking about the real world. 
[26]Where there is a Muslim majority -- that will be Pakistan. The rest is your India. 
[27]Let us worry about Pakistan -- you worry about India. 
[28]Now, please, if you've finished your prayers, could we begin with business. 
[29]It is your choice. Do you want an independent India and an independent Pakistan? Or do you want civil war?
dialogues.WALKER:
[1]It's news at the moment. I will certainly report on your mines and the economy -- but I would like to meet this Mr. Gandhi. 
[2]Hm. And what should an "important professional" write about your response to General Smuts's new legislation? 
[3]You will respect the law. 
[4]You're a very small minority to take on the Government -- and the Empire. 
[5]Well, it's quite a place, your "ashram" -- is that right? 
[6]You're an ambitious man. 
[7]They tell me you also take your turn at peeling potatoes and cleaning the "outhouse" -- is that part of the experiment? 
[8]Well, I read you account of that crowd in Calcutta and that he was twisting the Lion's tail again... 
[9]...and I knew something had to give. And I was determined to be here when it did. 
[10]Oh, I've been a Gandhi buff for a long time. 
[11]I met him once. 
[12]Back in South Africa... long time ago. 
[13]Lots of hair... and a little like a college freshman -- trying to figure everything out. 
[14]It's beautiful. 
[15]Trying to keep track of you is making me change all my sleeping habits. 
[16]Hm. Is it? 
[17]A great deal. 
[18]You know what you're going to do. 
[19]Where are you going? 
[20]on Gandhi's words to him 
[21]Is it over if they arrest you now? 
[22]What if they don't arrest you? What if they don't react at all? 
[23]He said he's in charge... 
[24]My name is Walk-er. And I intend to report it the way it is. 
[25]Hello! Ed! Ed! Goddammit, don't cut me off! Ed! Okay -- yeah -- right. 
[26]"They walked, with heads up, without music, or cheering, or any hope of escape from injury or death." "It went on and on and on. Women carried the wounded bodies from the ditch until they dropped from exhaustion. But still it went on." 
[27]"Whatever moral ascendance the West held was lost today. India is free for she has taken all that steel and cruelty can give, and she has neither cringed nor retreated." "In the words of his followers, 'Long live Mahatma Gandhi.' "
dialogues.MIRABEHN:
[1]You'd be Mr. Kallenbach. 
[2]I prefer the name Gandhiji has given me -- Mirabehn. 
[3]Might Mr. Nehru be there too? 
[4]You can't know how closely we follow your struggle -- how many in England admired what you did in Bardoli. It must have taken enormous courage. 
[5]And you're German... 
[6]And do you feel Indian? 
[7]But you've been with him so long -- why? 
[8]I -- I sent for it, from here. I dyed it myself. 
[9]It has. But you'd be surprised. They understand -- they really do. It's not the workers you have to worry about. 
[10]I would rather march. 
[11]I've brought your drinking water. May I turn you? 
[12]There is a little lemon juice in it. That is all. 
[13]Herman has gone to meet Pandit Nehru -- there was a telegram. Almost everywhere it has stopped. 
[14]I don't know... I know you are right. I don't know that this is right. 
[15]Panditji -- come in. 
[16]You should ride the pony. It is not necessary to walk to prove the point. 
[17]Bapu... 
[18]"Lead Kindly Light, amidst the circling gloom..." 
[19]His pulse is very irregular -- the kidneys aren't functioning. 
[20]Bapu, there's been no fighting -- anywhere. It has stopped -- the madness has stopped. 
[21]No... no. In every temple and mosque they have pledged to die before they lift a hand against each other. 
[22]He thinks he's failed. 
[23]I am blinded by my love of him, but I think when we most needed it, he offered the world a way out of madness. But he doesn't see it... and neither does the world.
dialogues.SMUTS:
[1]Yes -- ? 
[2]Did they? Well, they'll find we're a little better prepared this time. Mr. Gandhi will find he's on a long hiding to nothing. 
[3]But on a short trip, I wouldn't spend too much time on the Indian question, Mr. Walker. It's a tiny factor in South African life. 
[4]Of course. We Westerners have a weakness for these -- these spiritually inclined men of India. But as an old lawyer, let me warn you, Mr. Gandhi is as shrewd a man as you will ever meet, however "otherworldly" he may seem. But I'm sure you're enough of a reporter to see that. 
[5]Ah, Mr. Gandhi. I thought we might have a little talk. 
[6]Will you have a glass of sherry? 
[7]Perhaps some tea? 
[8]Ahh. 
[9]Please -- please do come and sit down. It's prison I wanted to talk to you about. 
[10]Mr. Gandhi, I've more or less decided to ask the House to repeal the Act that you have taken such "exception" to. 
[11]Hm. Of course it is not quite that simple. 
[12]I'm glad to hear you say that... very glad. You see if we repeal the Act under pressure under this kind of pressure it will create a great deal of resentment. Can you understand that? 
[13]Good. Good. I have thought of calling for a Royal Commission to "investigate" the new legislation. I think I could guarantee they would recommend the Act be repealed. 
[14]But they might also recommend that future Indian immigration be severely restricted -- even stopped. 
[15]You're an extraordinary man. 
[16]I'm ordering the release of all prisoners within the next twenty- four hours. You yourself are free from this moment. 
[17]Assuming we are in agreement? 
[18]All right. Fine. 
[19]Oh! Neither have I. I'm awfully sorry. 
[20]Daniels, would you lend Mr. Gandhi a shilling for a taxi? 
[21]How far will you be going, Mr. Gandhi? 
[22]He's either a great man or a colossal fraud... Either way, I shall be glad to see the last of him.
dialogues.KHAN:
[1]I'm rich -- but I'm Indian. I therefore do not expect to travel First Class. 
[2]That was England. 
[3]I can. But I risk being kicked into the gutter by someone less "holy" than Mr. Baker. 
[4]Allah be praised. And what battalions will you call upon? 
[5]I rather like the idea of an Indian barrister in South Africa. I'm sure our community could keep you in work for some time, Mr. Gandhi -- even if you caused a good deal of trouble. Especially if you caused a good deal of trouble. 
[6]You also said your article would draw a thousand people. At least some of the Hindus brought their wives. 
[7]You write brilliantly, but you have much to learn about handling men. 
[8]fluent, but firm and pointed 
[9]We will now burn the passes of our committee and its supporters. We ask you to put your passes on the fire with -- 
[10]He's become quite good at this. 
[11]No. You were the surprise. It's been all over the prison. We thought they'd be too afraid of the English press. 
[12]Don't worry about the meat -- it's Hindu -- there's not a trace. 
[13]I don't know who they've left out there to do the work. There can't be one mine left open. Have they touched the women? 
[14]The fools! Sorry... 
[15]Well, that's one victory. 
[16]Don't worry -- I've never seen men so determined. You've given them a way to fight... And I don't think --
dialogues.AZAD:
[1]And what "resistance" would you offer? 
[2]Three hundred fifty million people at prayer. Even the English newspapers would have to report that. And explain why. 
[3]It was a Hindu child and it tried to wet on me. 
[4]He was a she. 
[5]From the looks of the luggage, yes. 
[6]He came Second Class. 
[7]No. 
[8]...but then some rioting broke out between Hindus and Muslims -- violent, terrible... 
[9]Whether it was provoked... But it gave them an excuse to impose martial law throughout Bengal. Some of the things the military have done... 
[10]The marches and protests are bigger if anything but with the censorship here they know more in England than we do, and it saps the courage to think you may be suffering alone. 
[11]I would like admission to the Works. 
[12]Last night they took Gandhiji from us. They expect us to lose heart or to fight back. We will not lose heart, we will not fight back. In his name we will be beaten. As he has taught us, we will not raise a hand. "Long live Mahatma Gandhi!" 
[13]Aren't there any troops to spare? 
[14]Where are you going?
dialogues.DYER:
[1]Port arms, Sergeant Major. 
[2]Load. 
[3]They've had their warning -- no meetings. 
[4]Sergeant Major -- 
[5]Fire! 
[6]Take your time. Take your time. 
[7]Corporal! 
[8]Over there. 
[9]That is so. 
[10]My intention was to inflict a lesson that would have an impact throughout all India. 
[11]I think, probably -- yes. 
[12]I did. 
[13]That is correct. 
[14]I was ready to help any who applied.
dialogues.KALLENBACH:
[1]I do it as a friend -- and admirer -- not a servant. 
[2]Yes. Now that things are moving he's going to write and only take part when it's necessary. 
[3]There's another passenger -- a Miss Slade. She's the daughter of an English admiral. She's been corresponding with him for a year. 
[4]She wants to make her home with us -- and Gandhiji has agreed. 
[5]...And you would be Miss Slade. 
[6]It was a gift and it only worked a few weeks, but when Gandhi came home he struck on this idea. He calls it his ox-Ford. Comfortable -- and yet more our pace. 
[7]Yes. 
[8]No. 
[9]...I'd come to believe I would never meet a truly honest man. And then I met one. 
[10]Tomorrow. Tomorrow photograph him. 
[11]It is violence, and the fear of violence, that have made today what it is... Give him the dignity of his grief. 
[12]Gandhi will pray for them...
dialogues.IRWIN:
[1]Salt? 
[2]All right -- he's breaking the law. What will he be depriving us of, two rupees of salt tax? 
[3]Don't patronize me, Charles. 
[4]And that's the basis of this "Declaration of Independence"? 
[5]General Edgar is right -- ignore it. Mr. Gandhi will find it's going to take a great deal more than a pinch of salt to bring down the British Empire. 
[6]We're required to stop it. And stop it we will. I don't care if we fill the jails, stop it. Arrest anyone, any rank -- except Gandhi. We'll cut his strength from under him. And then we'll deal with the Mahatma. 
[7]Who's leading them? 
[8]I believe the question was intended to discover if there was any violence of their side. 
[9]He's addressed this letter directly to you, has he? 
[10]Thank him for his letter, and put him in jail. 
[11]And Fields, keep that salt works open. 
[12]Mr. Gandhi, I have instructions to request your attendance at an All- Government Conference in London to discuss -- to discuss the possible Independence of India.
dialogues.ENGLISH CAPTAIN:
[1]Clear the way there! Get out of the way! 
[2]Give me a leg up, will you! 
[3]What the hell is it, Sergeant? 
[4]Jesus...! 
[5]What the hell is going on? 
[6]Who the hell is he? 
[7]Who the devil are you? 
[8]Well, whoever you are, we don't want you here. I suggest you get back on that train before it leaves the station. 
[9]Now look here. I'll put you under arrest if you'd prefer? 
[10]I don't want any trouble. 
[11]Well, there'd better not be.
dialogues.SENIOR POLICE OFFICER:
[1]There is a Royal Monopoly on the manufacture of salt, sir. It's illegal to make it or sell it without a Government license. 
[2]Yes, sir. The day he sets off everyone is supposed to raise the flag of "Free India." Then he walks some two hundred and forty miles to the sea and makes salt. 
[3]They're making it everywhere, sir -- mobs of them -- publicly. Congress leaders are selling it on the streets of Delhi. 
[4]...There's been no time to keep figures, but there must be ninety -- a hundred thousand under arrest. And it still goes on. 
[5]I don't know! Nehru, Patel, almost every Congress Official is in jail... and their wives and their children -- we've even arrested Nehru's mother. 
[6]Oh, in Karachi the police fired on a crowd and killed a couple of people and -- and in Peshawar the Deputy Police Commissioner lost his head and... and opened fire with a machine gun. But he's facing a disciplinary court! You can't expect things like that not to happen when -- 
[7]Oh, no, sir -- no, I'm afraid not. 
[8]Yes, sir, he has. The usual -- India's salt belongs to India -- but then he says flatly that he personally is going to lead a raid tomorrow on the Dharasana Salt Works. 
[9]Yes, sir. Yes, sir. It will be my pleasure. 
[10]Yes, sir!
dialogues.SIR EDWARD:
[1]But good God, man, you yourself raised the rent simply to finance a hunting expedition! 
[2]And some of these others -- beatings, illegal seizures, demanding services without pay, even refusing them water! In India!... 
[3]Well, you've make this half-naked whatever-he-is into an international hero. 
[4]"One lone man marching dusty roads armed only with honesty and a bamboo shaft doing battle with the British Empire." At home children are writing "essays" about him. 
[5]I couldn't take another two years of him to save my life. 
[6]And His Majesty's Government. It only needs your signature for the landlords. 
[7]Perhaps. But at least all this has made the Government see some sense about what men like Mr. Gandhi should be allowed, and what they should be denied. 
[8]Things are going to change.
dialogues.CHELMSFORD:
[1]Yes? 
[2]Is it simply Delhi and Bombay? 
[3]I can't believe it... 
[4]Arrest him! 
[5]You must understand, gentlemen, that His Majesty's Government -- and the British people -- repudiate both the massacre and the philosophy that prompted it. 
[6]What I would like to do is to come to some compromise over the new civil legis -- 
[7]Even if His Majesty could waive all other considerations, he has a duty to the millions of his Muslim subjects who are a minority in this realm. And experience has taught that his troops and his administration are essential in order to keep the peace. 
[8]Yes -- but it would be wise to be very cautious for a time. The Anti- Terrorist Act will remain on the statutes, but on no account is Gandhi to be arrested. Whatever mischief he causes, I have no intention of making a martyr of him.
dialogues.SERGEANT:
[1]Stop! 
[2]At the canter -- for-ward! 
[3]You're right! 
[4]Follow me! 
[5]What the hell are we supposed to do now? 
[6]You're Nehru -- 
[7]I wouldn't have believed it, Mr. Gupta.
dialogues.MAGISTRATE:
[1]I am going to clear the courtroom. 
[2]I don't know where they found the nerve for all this. 
[3]How the press get here before the military? 
[4]You have been ordered out of the province on the grounds of disturbing the peace. 
[5]Do you want to go to jail? 
[6]All right. I will release you on bail of one hundred rupees until I reach a sentence. 
[7]Then I -- I will grant release without bail -- until I reach a decision.
dialogues.COLLINS:
[1]Well, he certainly wasn't forgotten! And as soon as he got out he was back tramping the country, preaching non-violence and demanding a free India. Everybody knows another showdown's coming -- but when, and over what -- 
[2]How does a reporter in Central America learn that Gandhi was born in Porbandar anyway? 
[3]He certainly makes good copy. The other day Winston Churchill called him "that half-naked Indian fakir." 
[4]You mean Gandhi? 
[5]What was he like? 
[6]Well, he must've found some of the answers... 
[7]What'd he say?
dialogues.POLICE SERGEANT:
[1]Oh, no, you bloody well don't! 
[2]Those passes are government property! And I will arrest the first man who tries to burn one! 
[3]Take him away! 
[4]Now -- are there any more?! 
[5]You little sammy bastard -- I -- 
[6]You want that kind of trouble -- you can have it!
dialogues.GOKHALE:
[1]We're trying to make a nation, Gandhi -- and the British keep trying to break us up into religions and principalities and "provinces." What you were writing in South Africa -- that's what we need here. 
[2]Nonsense. Go on, Charlie. This is Indian talk -- we want none of you imperialists. 
[3]Go and find a pretty Hindu woman and convert her to Christianity -- that's as much mischief as you're allowed. 
[4]Forget your practice. India has many men with too much wealth -- it is their privilege to nourish the efforts of the few who can raise India from servitude and apathy. I will see to it -- you begin your journal. 
[5]Well, change that. Go and find India. Not what you see here, but the real India. You'll see what needs to be said. What we need to hear. 
[6]When I saw you in that tunic I knew... I knew I could die in peace. Make India proud of herself.
dialogues.PRINCIPAL SECRETARY:
[1]Yes, sir. He is going to march to the sea and make salt. 
[2]It's not a serious attack on the revenue, sir. Its primary importance is symbolic. 
[3]No, sir. I -- in this climate, sir, nothing lives without water -- or salt. Our absolute control of it is a control on the pulse of India. 
[4]He's going to arrive at the sea on the anniversary of the massacre at Amritsar. 
[5]Has there been any violence? 
[6]Perhaps if we arrested Gandhi, it might --
